The given chunk describes an optimization technique within a document that explains how to reconstruct view-space positions in graphics programming. This specific part introduces precomputed constants (x_proj, y_proj, z_proj, w_proj) derived from the projection matrix to simplify calculations, leading to efficient equations for transforming screen-space coordinates back into view-space during shader processing.

To save our vertex and pixel shaders a little work, we can precompute these constants:

$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned} x_{proj} &= \frac{0.5D}{A} \\ y_{proj} &= 0.5D \\ z_{proj} &= \frac{0.5D}{C} \\ w_{proj} &= -0.5-0.5B \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$

So, here are the equations in their final form:

$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned} x_{view} &= \frac{x_{screen} \cdot x_{proj}}{depth + w} \\ y_{view} &= \frac{y_{proj}}{depth + w} \\ z_{view} &= \frac{y_{screen} \cdot z_{proj}}{depth + w} \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$
